data.description:
Our 100th batch, brewed for the enjoyment of the brewers, but popular demand forced us to release it commercially.
This malty, yet light bodied ale has a massive hop bitterness. Most enjoyable in a comfortable chair in front of a roaring fire.

style.name: Scottish-Style Light Ale
style.description: Scottish light ales are light bodied. Little bitterness is perceived, and hop flavor or aroma should not be perceived. Despite its lightness, Scottish light ale will have a degree of malty, caramel-like, soft and chewy character. Yeast characters such as diacetyl (butterscotch) and sulfuriness are acceptable at very low levels. The color will range from golden amber to deep brown Bottled versions of this traditional draft beer may contain higher amounts of carbon dioxide than is typical for mildly carbonated draft versions. Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Though there is little evidence suggesting that traditionally made Scottishstyle light ales exhibited peat smoke character, the current marketplace offers many Scottish-style light ales with peat or smoke character present at low to medium levels. Thus a peaty/smoky character may be evident at low levels (ales with medium or higher smoke character would be considered a smoke flavored beer and considered in another category). Scottish-style light ales may be split into two subcategories: Traditional (no smoke character) and Peated (low level of peat smoke character).

data.name: 12 Penny Scottish Ale
data.description: A Scottish export ale collaboration with Great Fermentations. This cold-conditioned ale puts a light hop on to balance the malt. Add in a nice, crisp finish and you've got a sessionable beer perfect to celebrate Spring, the end of the workday, good friends (consulting 1001 Things to be Happy About)*, peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, puppies, sand dollars...

data.description: Lighter Scotish-Style Ale... amber in color with plenty of maltiness... reminds us all that sometime there just aren't enough O's in smooth

data.name: 60 Shilling Ale
data.description: This beer is created in the 1850's style.  It is Scotland’s answer to the English Mild Ale. Brewed with Pale, Roasted Barley, and Crystal malt matched with Fuggles and Golding hops giving this beer a smooth and light flavor.

data.name: 70 Shilling Ale
data.description: This traditional lower-alcohol Scottish Ale is deceiving in its appearance. Deep brown in color with ruby/garnet highlights, the toasty-biscuity aroma gives way to a very light-bodied brew. Sweet malt flavors are dominant with a hint of fruit, not unlike black currants. A slight earthy character persists into the lightly chewy finish. Clean and refreshingly delicious.

data.name: 80 Shilling Ale
data.description: A special brew to celebrate the Town of Leesburg, our own Scottish style ale! Brewed with English pale and crystal malts and a touch of roasted barley, we also used flaked oats to lend a nice mouth feel. The hop varietal used was English First Gold and it was sparingly used like most Scots would. A rich mahogany color with an accent towards malt sweetness. Cheers!

data.description: A Scottich 80 with caramel and more bite than a typical ale, together with a bit of beach wood smoked malt to finish.

data.name: Ale of Fergus
data.description: Scottish Session Ale. Six types of malts go into this medal-winning Scottish Session Ale. Ruby brown in color, light to medium bodied with subtle flavors of caramel and toast. Bronze medal winner at the 2010 Great American Beer Festival -English Style MIld Ale Category.

data.name: Arctic Ale
data.description: For the beer drinkers who enjoy a mild-tasting, Canadian-style beer. This light ale is refreshing with a crisp, slightly hoppy start and a smooth dry finish.

data.name: Ballantrae
data.description: A light, sweet, traditional light Scottish ale, made with floor-malted British malt, a titch of Caramel malt, a touch of roasted barley, and the barest wisp of smoked malt along with traditional British hops, and Scottish ale yeast. An easy-drinking light dark beer for winter that pairs excellently with shortbread, mild sausage, and woody cheddars.

data.name: Brooklyn Winter Ale
data.description: When the days grow short and the beach recedes into our dreams, we need a very nice beer to get us through the long winter. Based on the satisfying malty ales of blustery Scotland, Brooklyn Winter Ale will have you looking on the bright side of things. Rich Scottish malts bring deep bready flavors to a beer with a full copper color, a round, smooth palate, and brisk hopping that pulls the sweet malts into balance. See - things are looking up already!
data.foodPairings: Brooklyn Winter Ale is great with robust winter foods such as stews, steaks, lamb, game, duck, pork, barbecue, and it's a very nice match for a wide variety of fine cheeses, particularly farmhouse cheddar and sheep’s milk cheese. And should you decide to enjoy a cigar in your favorite armchair in front of the fireplace, this beer will play along very nicely.

data.name: Caledonian 80/-
data.description:
Russet brown, smooth and creamy with a malty/fruity aroma. The definitive classic 80/- ale, full bodied, complex malt & hop flavours, dry but spicy. Characterised by a superb creamy head and soft hoppy finish.

As this is a malty Scottish ale it is well suited to all manner of great pub food, and complements red meat dishes, pies and hearty soups. For those looking for a more satisfying long drink this beer hits the mark being smooth, creamy and very easy on the palate.

data.name: Call the Banners
data.description: Brewed by warrior poets, Call The Banners is a Scottish 70 Schilling Ale that is made with Scottish yeast and bittered with Mt. Hood hops and dandelion greens. Light-bodied, with caramel and toffee notes, the tannins from the dandelions meld with a hint of smoke at the finish. In order to protect the realm from invading hordes, alliances were formed between houses. If your neighbor was in need, your house banner was called upon, leaving your home unprotected. When the banners are called will you answer the summons and stand in arms with your neighbor?

data.name: Cape May South Jersey Secession Session Scottish Ale
data.nameDisplay: Cape May South Jersey Secession Session Scottish Ale
data.description: Sometimes you’re looking to get a good buzz; sometimes not. But you never have to sacrifice quality. This malt-heavy and lightly hopped session ale is full in flavor but easy-drinking and low in ABV.

data.name: Captain Dunkin's Scottish Ale
data.description: Before being incarcerated for the siege of Charleston, Scottish pirate George Dunkin toasted his shipmates with a pint of Scottish ale. This sweet, malty ale is smoky, peaty, with hints of caramel and roasted coffee

data.name: CB's MacBubba
data.description:
Meet “MacBubba”. This BIG, good ol’ boy is Scottish to the core. He is bold, but absolutely loveable. Once you get to know MacBubba, you won’t know how you went anywhere without him. This Scotch Ale has a subtle smoky undertone not found in many other beers. Starting with a beautiful dark-amber color it has a nice rich aroma that follows with a full bodied caramel flavor. You will note a
slight “peaty” character in the finish, derived from the addition of some of the finest Peated Malt from Scotland. We think you will find this Scotch Ale very easy to enjoy while still bold enough to stand up to a harsh winter chill.
data.foodPairings: A perfect match with smoked meats, strong cheeses, and desserts. Also quite effective as a braising ale or in used in soups.

data.name: Corne de Brume
data.description:
Corne de Brume (The Air Horn) is a Scotch ale at 9.0% alcohol. In a deep brown with hints of ruby, she dons a mocha mousse aspects. This is the mouth Air Horn reveals its depth. A wall of caramelized flavor stands before us and surrounds us warmly language. This dance caramelized and lascivious binds with bitterness deaf to form a waltz which combines wild fruits and heady malt. Some time later, the bitterness release its grip on our taste buds to slowly bring us back to reality.
Beer aging potential

data.name: Dark Island
data.description:
Dark Island is an iconic beer: a standard-bearer for traditional Scottish ales. In cask, this beer has twice won CAMRA's Champion Beer of Scotland. On the nose, this dark beer offers bitter chocolate, figs, toffee and hints of fruit.

On the palate, this resolves into beautiful, silky-smooth, coffee-and-chocolate flavours, followed by figs, dates and dried fruits, with a very appealing, lingering aftertaste of fruits and hop bitterness.

style.name: Scottish-Style Light Ale
style.description: Scottish light ales are light bodied. Little bitterness is perceived, and hop flavor or aroma should not be perceived. Despite its lightness, Scottish light ale will have a degree of malty, caramel-like, soft and chewy character. Yeast characters such as diacetyl (butterscotch) and sulfuriness are acceptable at very low levels. The color will range from golden amber to deep brown Bottled versions of this traditional draft beer may contain higher amounts of carbon dioxide than is typical for mildly carbonated draft versions. Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Though there is little evidence suggesting that traditionally made Scottishstyle light ales exhibited peat smoke character, the current marketplace offers many Scottish-style light ales with peat or smoke character present at low to medium levels. Thus a peaty/smoky character may be evident at low levels (ales with medium or higher smoke character would be considered a smoke flavored beer and considered in another category). Scottish-style light ales may be split into two subcategories: Traditional (no smoke character) and Peated (low level of peat smoke character).

data.name: Dram Tree Scottish Ale
data.description: Our House specialty. Dark but smooth, maly and semi-sweet, with caramel tones and a slight mocha finish. Mahogany body with ruby highlights. So smooth, this beer is constantly turning regular light-beer drinkers to the dark side. Pale, Munich, Chocolate and Caramel malts make up the backbone of this Ale. Challenger and EKG hops are used sparingly.
data.foodPairings: Bacon, Scottish Ale Brew-Bq Sauce Ribs, Jim Beam Sirloin Steak

available.name: Year Round
available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

data.name: Fiddlin' Willies Scottish Ale
data.description: Wonderfully malty ale, with a dark reddish-brown color.  Caramalt and Chocolate malts dominate the flavor, with a hint of smokiness.  The East Kent Goldings hops are few in this brew, just enough for a slight balance. Toffee and chocolate flavors are evident.  Great for the malt lover in all of us.

data.name: Fresh Spring
data.description: Refreshing light ale, its colour is likened to daffodils. Brewed with a nice blend of malted barley with locally grown Fuggles hops for a gentle hop aroma and flavour. At 4.0% abv it is very drinkable.

data.name: Half Kilt
data.description: Cleanly malty with a drying finish. It has a relatively sweet palate that finishes dry with a touch of caramelizatian from the kettle. One of the original session beers.

data.name: Hullabaloo
data.description: Experience a world of hearty flavors and aromas with this special winter beer. This brew starts as a Scottish ale featuring European and Domestic malts, giving Hullabaloo intriguing caramel and roast nuances. A blend of American and English hops delivers ample bitterness & unique hop profile. This is a big, rich beer with a nice, underlying complexity – Toast to the Season!
data.foodPairings: Pulled Pork, smoked Trout, hard sheeps-milk chees

data.name: Imperial Topaz Amber
data.description: Scottish amber ale that is brewed with two row malt and roasted barley using a single noble British hop to compliment the malty rich flavor of this strong beer

data.name: Jolly Scot Scottish Ale
data.description: A rich amber color and deep layers of natural malt flavor make this a great session beer. Brewed with a complex blend of distinct caramel style malts and light hop additions, this ale is sweet and toasty on the palate, and smooth to the finish.

data.name: Kilted Gnome Scottish Ale
data.description: Wandering in the Black Forest, a Heinzelmannchen met up with a Scottish lass and they shared their favorite ale recipes. This meeting created the perfect marriage of Scottish and German culture with this result: a Scottish style ale An amber brown, light bodied, scottish style ale with a warming alcohol note, finishes flavorful, slightly sweet and hoppy.

style.description: Scottish light ales are light bodied. Little bitterness is perceived, and hop flavor or aroma should not be perceived. Despite its lightness, Scottish light ale will have a degree of malty, caramel-like, soft and chewy character. Yeast characters such as diacetyl (butterscotch) and sulfuriness are acceptable at very low levels. The color will range from golden amber to deep brown Bottled versions of this traditional draft beer may contain higher amounts of carbon dioxide than is typical for mildly carbonated draft versions. Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Though there is little evidence suggesting that traditionally made Scottishstyle light ales exhibited peat smoke character, the current marketplace offers many Scottish-style light ales with peat or smoke character present at low to medium levels. Thus a peaty/smoky character may be evident at low levels (ales with medium or higher smoke character would be considered a smoke flavored beer and considered in another category). Scottish-style light ales may be split into two subcategories: Traditional (no smoke character) and Peated (low level of peat smoke character).
